page.title: 03M5 M6 Interchange West Brom
page.content: When the M5&M6 interchange was planned the route chosen was one which ran along the wide flat valley of the River Tame. It had no large housing estate or built up area but was mostly occupied by smallfarms such as Wigmore Farm and waste land .The land in this area belonged mostly to West Bromwich Corporation. This land of the Tame Valley was obviously favoured as a routeway in the 19th century as both the railway and canal are built along the valley.The Grand Junction railway line runs through the north of our block along the Tame Valley to Birmingham following roughly the line of the river and the Tame Valley Canal. The M5 passes under the A4041(Newton Road) from there the M5 and the link road are built on embankments and concrete pillars at varied levels along the Tame Valley.
